summary: Walter Lloyd was an individual working within the Office of General Counsel at the CIA. The documents indicate his involvement in handling Privacy Act cases, specifically case 71-728 concerning Werbell. One document mentions an estimated completion date for this case, suggesting Lloyd was responsible for processing or overseeing the legal aspects of the case. The other documents relate to Mitchell Livingston Werbell III, indicating that Lloyd's work was connected to Werbell's case, though the exact nature of his involvement is not fully detailed in these documents.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Walter Lloyd's significance in the JFK assassination context is indirect. He appears to have been involved in handling legal matters related to individuals like Mitchell Livingston Werbell III, who may have had connections to the CIA. However, the documents do not explicitly link Lloyd to the JFK assassination itself. His role seems to be more related to the legal and administrative aspects of CIA operations and handling of sensitive cases involving individuals of interest.
